chapter.title: Installing ArgoUML
chapter.para:
This chapter presents step by step procedures for
checking ArgoUML system requirement
obtaining ArgoUML
installing ArgoUML

sect1.title: Can your computer run &argo;?
sect1.para: Before you can install and use &argo; you must ensure that your computer's configuration meets the minimum system requirements for running &argo;. To ensure that your computer can run &argo; properly we will check the following:

para.link: The version of the Java Platform installed on your computer (if any)

sect2.title: Check your computer's hardware specification
sect2.para:
&argo; is a complex application with an interactive, graphics editing user interface. The minimum recommended configuration for a computer running &argo; is shown below. Please check and ensure that your computer meets the following minimum requirements before installing or using &argo;:
Microsoft Windows 95/98/Me/NT/2000, Linux or other OS that supports Java2
200MHz Intel Pentium, AMD K6 or similar processor
64MB (128MB for Windows 2000) RAM
10MB of free disk storage space on your hard disk
SVGA video output and monitor
Mouse (or other pointing device) and a Keyboard

sect2.title: Check the version of Java on your computer
sect2.para: &argo; is a 100% Pure Java application. Your computer must have a version of the Java 2 platform JDK installed to use &argo;. More specifically, the Java 2 JDK v1.2 (i.e. JDK1.2 or later) is recommended for use with &argo;. Although &argo; has not been tested an all Java 2 platforms, it should run on all Java 2 installations regardless of the underlying OS platform.

note.para: Official Java 2 JDKs are available to download from Sun at http://java.sun.com/jdk/.

sect1.title: Installation options
sect1.para:
Now that you have a computer that can install and run &argo; effectively, you need to decide which of the installation options available is appropriate for you. You can choose from the following options:
Java Web Start option - this option is provided for first-time or occasional users. It is the easiest and quickest way to start using &argo;
Binary distribution option - this option is provided for regular users. You should also choose this option if you are having problems with the Java Web Start option.
Source or CVS distribution option - this option is provided for &argo; developers and contributors. You should choose this option if you are having problems with the other options.

sect2.title: Binary distribution option
sect2.para: This is the most common installation option for regular &argo; users. It involves obtaining a copy of the binary distribution archive from the &argo-website; and then preparing your computer to be able to run &argo; using the contents of the binary distribution. You should use this option if you are either unable or unwilling to run the Java Web Start version or, your computer is not directly connected to the internet or, you already have the binary distribution.

sect3.title: Obtain the &argo; binary distribution
sect3.para: If you haven't already done so, please download a copy of the binary distribution from the &argo-homepage;. If the computer on which &argo; will be installed is not connected to the internet, download the file using another computer and copy the binary distribution file to the target computer.

sect3.title: Create an &argo; installation directory
sect3.para: Create a directory on your computer for the &argo; application. This directory will thereafter be referred to as the &argo; installation directory or just as ARGOUML_HOME. Sample commands for creating an &argo; installation directory on computers running Windows and Linux are shown below. You might want to choose a different location for &argo; on your computer.

informalexample.para:
Sample commands for Windows
mkdir C:\OO-Tools\&argo;

Sample commands for Linux and other Unixes
md /usr/bin/&argo;

blockquote.para:
Sample commands for Windows
mkdir C:\OO-Tools\&argo;

Sample commands for Linux and other Unixes
md /usr/bin/&argo;

sect3.title: Extract the &argo; files to the installation directory
sect3.para: You will now change the current directory to the &argo; installation directory you have just created and extract the files contained in the binary distribution to the directory. The general form of the command to extract the files is:

As an example, let's say you have an &argo; binary distribution archive named ArgoUML-0.9.3.zip that it is stored in a directory called C:\Distributions or ~/distributions on a Windows or Linux computer respectively. To extract the &argo; files from the archive, you would type the following commands on the Windows and Linux/Unix platforms.

example.title: Extracting &argo; files from binary distribution
example.programlisting:
chdir C:\OO-Tools\&argo; jar xvf C:\Distributions\ArgoUML-0.9.3.zip
cd /usr/bin/&argo; jar xvf ~/distributions/ArgoUML-0.9.3.zip

example.title: Extracting &argo; files from binary distribution

note.para: For the above command to work, the bin sub-directory of the JDK directory tree must be added to your PATH environment variable. You might also be able to use a compatible de-archiver such as winzip or gzip to extract the files.

sect3.para: You should now have the &argo; application's files copied to the installation directory on your system.

sect2.title: Source or CVS distribution option
sect2.para: This is the preferred installation option for &argo; developers, contributors and advanced users. It involves obtaining the &argo; source code as a distribution from the &argo-website; or from CVS, building &argo; on your computer, and then preparing your computer to run &argo;.

You should use this option if you want to keep up with the latest developments, you are a developer or contributor on the &argo; project or if you have problems using the other installation options. Please note however that the devlopment copy of &argo; is quite often unstable and is not advised for production use.

sect3.title: Obtain the &argo; source code
sect3.para: You can obtain the &argo-source; via one of two methods:

listitem.para: Source archive - this is a snapshot of the entire &argo; source code that is updated for each release (and maybe at other times too). This is the easiest way to get the &argo; source code but the contents may not be the latest available &argo; source code. You will need to obtain two archive files, one for the &argo; source code and one for the add-ons that &argo; depends on.

CVS checkout - in this case you will extract the latest copy of the &argo; source code from the public CVS database that the &argo-project-link; uses to track the development of &argo; itself. This is really only recommended for developers and other contributors as the latest source code is also the least stable version of &argo;. When you use this method, what you get is always a snapshot of &argo;'s source code as it is being developed.

sect3.para: If you haven't already done so, please please obtain a copy of the &argo-source; here. If the computer on which &argo; will be installed is not connected to the internet, download the file(s) using another computer and copy the file(s) to the target computer.

sect3.title: Extract the &argo; source code (source archive method only)
sect3.para: If you have chosen to obtain the &argo; source distribution archive(s), you need to extract the files from the archive(s) to a directory on your computer before you can build your copy &argo;.

Firstly, create a directory on your computer for the &argo; source code. This directory will thereafter be referred to as the &argo; source directory or just as ARGOSOURCE_HOME. Sample commands for creating an &argo; source directory on computers running Windows and Linux are shown below. You might want to choose a different location for &argo; on your computer.

blockquote.para:
Sample commands for Windows
mkdir C:\OO-Tools\&argo;-source

Sample commands for Linux and other Unixes
md /usr/bin/&argo;-source

sect3.para: Next, change the current directory to the &argo; source directory you have just created and extract the files contained in the source distribution archive(s) to the directory. The general form of the command to extract the files is:

As an example, given the following assumption on a Windows computer (with Linux/Unix-specific details in brackets):
an &argo; source archive named ArgoUML-0.9.3-src.zip (ArgoUML-0.9.3-src.tar.gz on Linux/Unix)
an &argo; add-ons source archive named ArgoUML-0.9.3-libs.zip (ArgoUML-0.9.3-libs.tar.gz on Linux/Unix)
both source archives are stored in the directory C:\Distributions (~/distributions on Linux/Unix)
To extract the files from both archives to the &argo; source directory, you would type the following commands on the Windows and Linux/Unix platforms.

blockquote.para:
Sample commands for Windows
chdir C:\OO-Tools\&argo;-source jar xvf C:\Distributions\ArgoUML-0.9.3-src.zip jar xvf C:\Distributions\ArgoUML-0.9.3-libs.zip

Sample commands for Linux and other Unixes
cd /usr/bin/&argo;-source jar xvf ~/distributions/ArgoUML-0.9.3-src.tar.gz jar xvf ~/distributions/ArgoUML-0.9.3-libs.tar.gz

note.para: For the above command to work, the bin sub-directory of the JDK directory tree must be added to your PATH environment variable. You might also be able to use a compatible de-archiver such as winzip or gzip to extract the files.

sect3.para: You should now have the &argo; application's source files copied to the &argo; source directory on your system.

sect1.title: About this guide...
sect1.para: This guide - the &document-title; - is provided to help you get up and running as quickly as possible with ArgoUML. It provides step-by-step instructions for obtaining and installing ArgoUML, performing common tasks, and outlines your options for contact the &argo-project-link; team should you need further support or to contribute to ArgoUML's development.
